repnme.cdata!:
Solomon Islands - Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is assessed unsatisfactory,
            with unlikely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impacts. Lessons indicate that for
            macroeconomic, and structural reforms to succeed, a stable
            political environment is essential, as demonstrated by the
            project experience, when during the country's political
            stability the economic reform program did progress, in
            contrast to its deterioration, during the intensification of
            the ethnic crisis. An effective donor coordination is
            crucial, particularly in small states under capacity
            constraints, where implementation of structural reforms is
            extremely difficult, and can be overwhelmed by a large
            number of donors. Similarly, assessing the degree of risk in
            a diversely ethnic state is critical, though extremely
            difficult: despite the highlighted ethnicity risks at
            appraisal, it was not possible to measure the depth, and
            intensity of the crisis, which set back the progress made by
            reforms, and stabilization efforts. It is suggested that
            future reform efforts, could include measures to help
            address the root causes of the crisis, i.e., uneven regional
            development, in a multi-ethnic country. Moreover, capable,
            and committed policymakers, are key to a successful program,
            exemplified by the Prime Minister's commitment to the
            implementation of the structural reform program; likewise,
            close dialogue between the Bank, and government
            counterparts, significantly improve the quality of Bank assistance.

repnme.cdata!:
Solomon Islands - Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Structural Adjustment Credit Project
            supports the economic reform program launched by the
            government in response to the economic crisis. The crisis
            reflects the cumulative effects of years of poor economic
            management and weak fiscal discipline, exacerbated by the
            East Asian financial crisis and the collapse of its major
            export markets for logs. The project will help restore
            macroeconomic stability and move the economy to a path of
            sustainable growth and development, while mitigating the
            social cost of adjustment. The structural reforms will be
            implemented in the areas of : a) the public sector,
            reduction of the scope of government, rightsizing and
            restructuring of government and the civil service, and
            strengthening of planning, budget, accounting, and
            monitoring systems; b) the financial sector, normalization
            of financial relations with the government, liberalization,
            and strengthening of the Central Bank's regulatory and
            supervisory powers and capacities; c) forestry, measures to
            reduce exploitation to sustainable levels, minimize the
            environmental impact and benefit development; and d) private
            sector development, measures to stimulate a supply response,
            and improvements in public expenditure allocation to benefit
            the poor and vulnerable groups.
